description.narrative: Stöd till Danish Committee for Aid to Afghan Refugees (DACAAR) för insatser inom vatten, hygien och sanitet i provinserna Balkh, Kunduz och Takhar, i Afganistan 2013-2014.
Support to Danish Committee for Aid to Afghan Refugees (DACAAR) for WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygine Promotion) interventions in the provinces Balkh, Kunduz and Takhar in Afgahnistan 2013-2014.

participating-org.narrative: DACAAR/Danish Committee for Aid to Afghan Refugee

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The project entitled “Provision of Safe Drinking Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Education to Vulnerable Communities in Balkh, Kunduz and Takhar Provinces” was implemented on 15 June 2013 and ended on 31 December 2015. The overall objective of the project is to “improve the quality of life in Balkh, Kunduz and Takhar provinces by availing safe drinking water, reducing waterborne disease and decreasing the burden of water collection”. To achieve this objective, DACAAR constructed 1,002 new water points providing safe drinking water to 120,925 individuals (19,675 Families). The 1,002 water points consisted of 380 tube wells in Kunduz, 300 tube wells and 121 stand posts in Balkh, and 141 tube wells and 60 stand posts in Takhar respectively. All tube wells were fitted with quality hand pumps. In addition to the above, 529 water points were reactivated in Kunduz (299), Balkh (110) and Takhar (120) provinces benefiting 61,761 individuals (10,945 Families), while 4,100 bio-sand filters (BSF) were distributed for families/household water treatment in Kunduz (900), Balkh (2,050) and Takhar (1,150) provinces benefiting 31,847 individuals (4,100 Families). The project also included support for latrine construction and hygiene education. In total, support for the construction of 3,003 hygienic latrines (three per water point) was provided to selected vulnerable families to be used as samples for replication. In order to achieve a sustainable change in hygiene behaviour and real impact of the health of the targeted population, all Water User Groups (WUGs) received hygiene education through household visits conducted by DACAAR Hygiene Educators. In total 24,546 families received hygiene education, which also included the distribution of 23,757 hygiene kits.
A total of 6,609 water points were inspected by the water points inspection team. This resulted in 212 water points being repaired by the community, assisted by the Water Inspection Team and mechanics during the life span of the project. 10 new monitoring wells were drilled in public compounds (schools) in Balkh, Kunduz and Takhar provinces and measuring equipment installed.
Resilience to natural disasters was built in communities through the establishment of 229 Disaster Management Committees which were linked with Provincial Disaster Management Committees (PDMCs).
The provision of safe drinking water has contributed to decreasing the impact of drought, which continues to be a major problem in these provinces. Overall, provision of safe drinking water, has provided a sufficient quantity of water to the beneficiaries and reduced the workload associated with water collection especially benefitting women and children. This in turn, and in addition to the provision of hygienic latrines and hygiene education, has contributed to a reduction in the occurrence of waterborne diseases.
16 training workshops, attended by 292 participants, were conducted on various WASH sector subjects in Kunduz, Balkh and Takhar provinces respectively.
This project benefitted a total of 34,720 families or 214,533 (116,190 women, 98,343 men) individuals.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
